name: Pirates of the Gulf
era_description: Caribbean Sea, 1822-1825. The US Navy's West Indies Squadron hunts the last generation of Caribbean pirates in the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Choose your fleet size and face legendary pirates like Cofresí, Lafitte, and Diabolito in this irregular battlefield.
about:
Pirates of the Gulf

The Final Chapter of Caribbean Piracy

The West Indies Anti-Piracy Operations (1814-1825)

By the 1820s, the romantic "Golden Age of Piracy" had long since ended, but a brutal resurgence of piracy plagued the Caribbean. Following the Spanish American wars of independence, Spanish naval power in the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea had collapsed, creating a power vacuum that pirates eagerly exploited. What had once been dashing privateers serving national interests devolved into ruthless criminals preying on merchant vessels of all nations.

The crisis came to a head in September 1821 when pirates captured three American merchant ships in a single coordinated attack. An outraged United States Congress authorized Commodore James Biddle to deploy a dedicated anti-piracy fleet to the Caribbean—the West Indies Squadron. This force consisted of two frigates (USS Macedonian and USS Congress), two corvettes, two sloops-of-war, multiple brigs and schooners, and over 1,500 naval personnel. It was the largest concentrated naval operation the young American republic had ever mounted in peacetime.

The campaign was relentless. Between 1822 and 1825, American and British naval forces pursued pirates across the Antilles, focusing primarily on Cuba, Puerto Rico, and the Bahamas. Unlike earlier anti-piracy efforts that confined themselves to sea battles, this operation specifically targeted pirate bases on land. Shore parties in civilian clothes infiltrated pirate havens, naval vessels blockaded known anchorages, and coordinated raids destroyed pirate infrastructure that had operated openly for years.

The pirates fought back with desperate ferocity. In July 1820 alone, American revenue cutters Alabama and Louisiana captured nine pirate ships in a series of running battles off the Louisiana coast. The American schooner USS Enterprise broke up pirate establishments at Cape San Antonio, capturing vessels and freeing hostages. British warships joined the hunt, and the combined pressure proved overwhelming.

The operation's success came at tremendous cost. Tropical disease ravaged the American warships, forcing entire squadrons back to port for months at a time. Yellow fever, malaria, and dysentery killed more sailors than pirate cutlasses ever did. By early 1824, most ships had been recalled due to illness, allowing piracy to briefly surge again in Puerto Rican waters.

The final blow came in March 1825 with the capture of Roberto Cofresi, Puerto Rico's most notorious pirate, and his sloop Anne. After Cofresi's execution, organized piracy in the Caribbean essentially ceased. While isolated incidents continued sporadically into the early 20th century, the West Indies Squadron had achieved its mission. The operation established anti-piracy doctrines still practiced by the modern U.S. Coast Guard and demonstrated that eliminating piracy required not just naval superiority at sea, but the political will to attack pirate sanctuaries on land.

A Gallery of Rogues Across Time

An Important Note on Historical Accuracy: The pirate captains in this game are drawn from different periods of Caribbean piracy, spanning nearly 150 years. They could never have sailed together in reality—some were already legendary when others were born. We've assembled this anachronistic "dream team" of history's most notorious buccaneers to create varied and challenging opponents. Think of it as a "greatest hits" collection of piracy rather than a historically accurate simulation of any single period.

The Pirate Captains

Edward "Blackbeard" Teach (c. 1680-1718)

Active: 1716-1718 | Origin: Bristol, England

Perhaps the most infamous pirate in history, Edward Teach built his legend in barely two years of actual piracy. Beginning his career under Benjamin Hornigold in 1716, Blackbeard quickly earned his own command and captured the French slave ship La Concorde, converting her into the 40-gun Queen Anne's Revenge with a crew of 300 men.

Blackbeard's genius lay in psychological warfare. He cultivated a terrifying image: slow-burning fuses woven into his thick black beard during battle, wreathing his face in smoke; multiple pistols and cutlasses strapped across his chest; and a reputation for hell-raising violence. Yet remarkably, there are no verified accounts of him ever murdering his captives. He relied on fear, not actual brutality, to compel surrender—and it worked spectacularly.

His most audacious act came in May 1718 when he blockaded Charleston, South Carolina for nearly a week. Ships attempting to enter or leave the harbor were seized, prominent citizens including council member Samuel Wragg were taken hostage, and Blackbeard demanded an unusual ransom: a chest of medicines. When the drugs were delivered, he released his prisoners unharmed, though stripped of their possessions and fine clothing.

Blackbeard accepted the King's Pardon in June 1718 and briefly retired to Bath, North Carolina, even marrying a local planter's daughter. But the sea called him back, and on November 22, 1718, Royal Navy Lieutenant Robert Maynard cornered him at Ocracoke Inlet. In a ferocious final battle, Teach reportedly suffered five gunshot wounds and twenty sword cuts before falling. Maynard severed his head and hung it from his ship's bowsprit as proof of death. Thus ended the two-year reign of piracy's most legendary figure.

Anne Bonny (c. 1698-1782)

Active: 1720 | Origin: Near Cork, Ireland

Anne Bonny shattered every expectation of 18th-century womanhood. Born illegitimately to an Irish lawyer and his housemaid, she emigrated to Charles Town (Charleston), South Carolina as a child. Her father became a successful merchant and plantation owner, but Anne proved uncontrollable—drinking in taverns, associating with sailors, and scandalizing polite society with her wild behavior.

When she married the poor sailor James Bonny in 1718, her outraged father disowned her. The couple moved to Nassau in the Bahamas, where James became an informant for Governor Woodes Rogers, turning in pirates for bounty money. Anne, meanwhile, spent her time in waterfront taverns where she met the flamboyant pirate John "Calico Jack" Rackham. She abandoned her husband and joined Rackham's crew, disguising herself as a man.

Anne proved to be one of the fiercest fighters aboard Rackham's ship. According to contemporary accounts, she was quick-tempered, skilled with pistol and cutlass, and absolutely fearless in battle. One legend claims she once stabbed a male crewmember through the heart for making comments about women bringing bad luck to ships. When Governor Rogers issued a proclamation listing Rackham's crew as enemies of the Crown in September 1720, Anne Bonny was specifically named—unusual recognition for any pirate, unprecedented for a woman.

Her career lasted only three months. On November 15, 1720, privateer Jonathan Barnet caught Rackham's crew drinking with English sailors. While the male pirates fled below deck in drunken panic, Anne and her crewmate Mary Read were the only ones who fought back, reportedly cursing their cowardly companions even as they were overwhelmed and captured.

At trial, Rackham and the male crew were hanged within weeks. Anne and Mary both "pleaded their bellies"—claimed pregnancy to delay execution. Legend says Anne's last words to Rackham before his execution were: "If you had fought like a man, you need not have been hanged like a dog." After Mary died in prison, Anne's wealthy father appears to have secured her release. She returned to Charles Town, remarried respectably, bore eight more children, and lived to age 84—a shockingly conventional ending for such an unconventional life.

Mary Read (c. 1695-1721)

Active: 1720 | Origin: England (possibly Bristol)

Mary Read's entire life was a masquerade. According to the largely unreliable General History of the Pyrates, her mother dressed her as a boy from childhood to deceive her late husband's mother into continuing financial support. Whether this story is true or embellished, Mary certainly spent most of her life living as a man.

She served in the British military in Flanders, fought in land battles, and reportedly fell in love with a fellow soldier—revealing her true sex only to him. They married, left the army, and ran an inn called "The Three Horseshoes" near Breda. When her husband died, Mary returned to men's clothing and went to sea as a sailor.

Her ship was captured by pirates in the West Indies around 1720. Mary joined their crew—whether voluntarily or by force remains unclear. She eventually made her way to Nassau and joined John Rackham's crew, where she met Anne Bonny. The two women formed a formidable partnership, both fighting in men's clothes and proving themselves equal to any male pirate in combat.

According to Johnson's sensationalized account, Anne initially believed Mary was "an especially beautiful man" and pursued her romantically, only to discover her true sex when Mary revealed herself. Whether they became lovers (as some historians suggest) or remained close friends, both women gained legendary status as the fiercest fighters aboard Rackham's ship. They were known to pick fights with crewmembers who insulted them and fought with particular savagery in battle.

When Barnet captured the ship in November 1720, Mary Read fought alongside Anne while the male pirates cowered below. At trial on November 28, 1720, both women were convicted and sentenced to hang, but both claimed pregnancy. Mary died in her Jamaican prison cell in April 1721, either from fever or complications of childbirth. She was buried on April 28, 1721 in Saint Catherine Parish, her grave marked simply: "Mary Read, Pirate." Unlike Anne, she never lived to see freedom again.

John "Calico Jack" Rackham (1682-1720)

Active: 1718-1720 | Origin: England

John Rackham earned his colorful nickname from his penchant for wearing flamboyant calico clothing—brightly patterned cotton imported from India that most pirates avoided as too conspicuous. But Calico Jack was always more showman than warrior, more style than substance. His greatest claim to fame lies not in his own exploits, but in the remarkable women who sailed with him.

Rackham served as quartermaster under Captain Charles Vane before a disagreement over tactics led to a crew vote that deposed Vane and elevated Rackham to captain in 1718. He accepted the King's Pardon later that year but quickly returned to piracy, stealing the sloop William from Nassau harbor in August 1720—an act that placed him permanently outside the law.

His three-month piracy career was unremarkable by the standards of the day: some captured fishing boats, a few merchant vessels, minor coastal raids. What made Rackham noteworthy was his willingness to have women aboard his ship—first Anne Bonny, whom he'd wooed away from her husband, then Mary Read. This violated one of piracy's strongest superstitions, but Rackham seems to have been more concerned with romance than tradition.

His end came swiftly and ignominiously. On the night of November 15, 1720, privateer Jonathan Barnet caught Rackham's crew entertaining English sailors they'd invited aboard for drinks. When Barnet attacked, most of the crew—including Rackham himself—were too drunk to fight and fled below deck. Only Anne Bonny and Mary Read stayed on deck, fighting desperately and cursing their cowardly male companions.

At his trial on November 16, 1720, Rackham was quickly convicted and sentenced to hang. His body was gibbeted—displayed in an iron cage at a small cay off Port Royal as a warning to other would-be pirates. The location became known as "Rackham's Cay" and remains so today. Anne Bonny reportedly visited him before his execution and delivered her famous rebuke: "If you had fought like a man, you need not have been hanged like a dog."

Today, Rackham is remembered less for his achievements than for his association with two of history's most remarkable female pirates, and for designing the Jolly Roger flag with crossed swords beneath a skull—a symbol that became synonymous with piracy itself.

The Reality Behind the Romance

The Caribbean pirates of popular imagination—swashbuckling adventurers seeking freedom and treasure—existed alongside a darker reality. Most pirates came from desperate poverty, naval desertion, or forced impressment. Life aboard a pirate vessel was brutal: constant danger, tropical disease, frequent hunger, and savage violence. Few pirates lived long enough to enjoy their plunder, and fewer still died peacefully.

The 1820s anti-piracy campaigns finally ended what naval warfare alone could not. By combining overwhelming force at sea with the political will to attack pirate havens on land, the United States and Great Britain broke piracy's back in the Caribbean. The romantic age of buccaneers gave way to the age of commerce, and the shipping lanes they'd terrorized for two centuries finally became safe for legitimate trade.

Yet the legends persist. Blackbeard's burning beard, Anne Bonny's defiance, Mary Read's masquerade, and the brief, brilliant flash of Caribbean piracy continue to capture imaginations worldwide. In Battle for the Oceans: Pirates of the Gulf, we bring these legends together for one final confrontation—a gathering that history never allowed, but that tactical strategy games can finally make possible.

Command your fleet. Face history's most notorious pirates. And discover whether you have what it takes to bring down the rogues who once ruled these waters.

promotional.marketing_description: Command the West Indies Squadron against the final generation of Caribbean pirates. Navigate treacherous waters, shallow reefs, and island hideouts in this sprawling Gulf of Mexico battlefield. Face up to four legendary pirate captains simultaneously!
features: Terrain-based tactics: shoals, reefs, shipping lanes

alliances.name: US Navy
alliances.description: West Indies Squadron - Hunt down the last generation of Caribbean pirates with disciplined naval tactics and superior firepower. Your frigates and schooners must navigate treacherous waters to bring law and order to the Gulf.

alliances.name: Pirates
alliances.description: Caribbean Buccaneers - A loose alliance of the last great pirate captains. Fast schooners and sloops can navigate shallow reefs where Navy frigates cannot follow. Strike from island hideouts and vanish into the shoals!

ai_captain.name: Roberto Cofresí
ai_captain.description: El Pirata Cofresí - The Robin Hood of Puerto Rico. Uses aggressive probability targeting and bold hit-and-run tactics from island hideouts.

pirate_fleets.description: The Robin Hood of Puerto Rico. Known for distributing loot to the poor while evading Spanish and American naval forces.

ai_captain.name: Jean Lafitte
ai_captain.description: The Gentleman Pirate - Master smuggler of Barataria Bay. Known for cunning tactics and switching between hunt and target modes like a true predator.

pirate_fleets.description: Gentleman pirate and hero of New Orleans. Lafitte's Baratarian smugglers know every hidden cove and channel in the Gulf.

ai_captain.name: Anne Bonney
ai_captain.description: The Fierce Pirate Queen - One of the fiercest fighters to ever sail the Caribbean. Quick-tempered, skilled with pistol and cutlass, and absolutely fearless in battle. Switches between hunt and target modes with savage precision.

pirate_fleets.description: The legendary female pirate who shattered every expectation of 18th-century womanhood. Anne Bonney's crew fights with the same fearlessness and ferocity as their captain—quick to anger, deadly with blade and pistol, and never backing down from a fight.

ai_captain.name: Diabolito
ai_captain.description: The Little Devil - Most feared pirate in Cuban waters. Ruthless and unpredictable, combines aggressive targeting with intimate knowledge of reef systems.

pirate_fleets.description: The Little Devil of Cuba. Brutal and unpredictable, his ships strike merchant vessels along the Florida Straits before vanishing into Cuban coves.

ai_captain.name: Edward Teach
ai_captain.description: Blackbeard himself! The most infamous pirate who ever lived. Terror of the Caribbean, master of intimidation, and brilliant tactician who strikes fear with aggressive probability attacks.

pirate_fleets.description: The ghost of Blackbeard returns! Though Edward Teach fell in 1718, his legend lives on. This fleet sails under his black flag, striking terror into the hearts of Navy sailors.

transition: The Caribbean sun beats down as sails fill with wind - engage the enemy!
Pirate sails spotted on the horizon - all hands to battle stations!
The hunt for Caribbean pirates begins - show no mercy!
player_win: Victory! The pirate threat is eliminated!
The Gulf is secure! All pirate vessels sent to the depths!
Outstanding naval command! The Caribbean is safe once more!
player_lose: Your squadron is destroyed! The pirates escape to fight another day!
Defeat! The West Indies Squadron has fallen!
The pirates scatter your fleet! The Gulf remains dangerous waters!
opponent_win: {opponent}: Your Navy vessels sink beneath Caribbean waves!
{opponent}: Run back to your ports - these waters belong to pirates!
{opponent}: Tell your commodore his squadron lies at the bottom!
opponent_lose: {opponent}: Curse you! My fleet is destroyed!
{opponent}: The Navy wins this day, but we'll return!
messages.attack_hit_size_small: HIT at {cell}! Contact reports small vessel!
messages.attack_hit_size_large: HIT at {cell}! Large capital ship detected!
messages.opponent_attack_miss: {opponent} fires at {cell} - their shot goes wide.
messages.defeat: Defeat! Your squadron has been sunk.
messages.game_end: Battle complete! {winner} controls the Caribbean after {turns} turns!
